q: Are your paints vegan?
a: Yes. Tikkurila paints are 100% synthetic and contain no animal by-products (e.g., shellac, casein).

q: Are Tikkurila’s products or raw materials tested on animals?
a: Tikkurila does not test its paints on animals. Under REACH, some raw chemical substances may be animal-tested by suppliers for safety.

q: Can I use your wall paints on ceilings?
a: Yes, but Anti-Reflex 2 is recommended for ceilings: dead-matt, non-flash, great in critical light and easy to touch up.

q: How long does my paint need to cure?
a: Allow about 1 month for water-based paints to reach maximum durability.

q: What does 'minimum contents' on the can mean?
a: Cans are filled in Finland; labelled minimum content may be ~10% less than the nominal unit due to measured fill at supply.

q: What type of paint can be used on radiators?
a: Use Helmi 10 or Helmi 30; for bare metal, prime with Helmi Primer. Topcoats: Everal Aqua 10/40/80 or Helmi 10/30/80.

q: Can I paint laminates?
a: Yes—with sanding, thorough cleaning, and an adhesion primer to help the paint key.

q: How do I paint a previously glossed interior wood surface?
a: Lightly sand and clean, then use Otex Akva or Otex Adhesion Primer before your chosen topcoat.

q: What is the maximum thinning rate for Helmi topcoats?
a: Do not thin Helmi furniture paints by more than ~20%. Check the product TDS for method-specific ratios.

q: Which primer/undercoat do I need?
a: Typical picks: Optiva Primer (walls), Luja Universal Primer (humid walls), Helmi Primer (interior wood), Ultra Primer (exterior wood), Hydrosol Primer (exterior masonry), Otex Akva (tricky interiors), Otex Adhesion Primer (tricky exteriors).

q: I want to return something I’ve ordered—what do I do?
a: Submit a return request and follow the Returns Policy; eligible items can be returned according to the site’s instructions.

q: Do you offer finance?
a: Yes—finance options are available via Klarna (subject to status).

q: What does ‘minimum contents’ mean on the can?
a: Cans are filled in Finland at ~10% under the nominal volume to allow space for colourant added during tinting for accurate colour.

q: Do you have Technical Data Sheets (TDS) and Safety Data Sheets (SDS)?
a: Yes—download them from each product page; MSDS/SDS also available on request via email.

q: What’s the difference between water-based and oil-based paint?
a: Water-based uses water as the thinner (fast-drying, low odour, lower VOC); oil-based uses solvents (stronger odour, higher VOC).

q: What is Tikkurila’s whitest white?
a: Lumi White (in the Lumi range) is the most brilliant white—great for crisp trims and ceilings.

q: Can you provide a RAL or BS code for Tikkurila colours?
a: No—we don’t provide RAL/BS references for Tikkurila’s own colours, but our paints are available in full BS, NCS, and RAL ranges.

q: How is colour matching done?
a: A spectrophotometer reads your sample; measurements are converted into a tint formula to create your custom colour.

q: Are Tikkurila products suitable for spray application?
a: Yes—many products suit airless, air-assisted, HVLP, and conventional spray; check each TDS for exact setup.

q: Can Helmi be sprayed with a gravity-fed gun when thinned?
a: Yes—Helmi range supports brush, roller, and spray; see Helmi TDS for tip sizes and thinning guidance.

q: What’s the best paint for ceilings?
a: Use Anti-Reflex White [2] for a dead-matt, non-flashing ceiling finish and easy touch-ups.

q: What should I use in a bathroom?
a: Use the Luja system: Luja Universal Primer + a Luja topcoat (7/20/40) for high humidity and frequent cleaning.

q: Can I paint laminate furniture or doors?
a: Yes. Clean and sand to de-gloss, then prime with Otex Akva or Otex Adhesion Primer. Finish with Helmi or Everal Aqua.

q: Which paint for radiators?
a: Prime bare metal with Helmi Primer or Rostex (as appropriate). Topcoat with Everal Aqua 10/40/80 or Helmi 10/30/80.

q: Can I paint ceramic tiles?
a: Use Luja Ceramic Tiles system: clean, abrade, follow the system TDS; suitable for many interior tiled areas.

q: What does Class 1 scrub resistance mean?
a: It’s the highest EN 13300 wet scrub rating—very durable and washable (e.g., Optiva Matt [5], Optiva Ceramic [3]).

q: How do I block stains or nicotine/tannin bleed?
a: Use a sealer/primer like Akrostop or Multistop on interior walls/ceilings after cleaning and drying the surface.

q: Exterior wood: opaque or translucent?
a: Opaque hides grain (e.g., Valtti Opaque, Pika-Teho). Translucent shows grain (e.g., Ultra Classic, Valtti Color). Choose based on look and maintenance.

q: Can I paint uPVC?
a: Yes. Thoroughly clean/degrease, lightly abrade, prime with Otex Akva/Adhesion Primer, then finish with Helmi or Everal Aqua.

q: Do you offer paint testers?
a: Yes—Interior Paint Colour Tester and Exterior Wood Stain & Paint Tester are available to sample shades before buying.

q: Can I paint over mould or mildew?
a: No—kill and clean it first with a suitable mould remover. Let dry fully, then prime/seal if staining remains and finish with a moisture-resistant system (e.g., Luja in bathrooms).

q: How long between coats?
a: Most water-borne products recoat in ~2–4 hours at 23°C/50% RH. Always check the product TDS for exact times.

q: What temperature and humidity can I paint in?
a: Work on a dry surface, typically above +5°C and below ~80% RH. Avoid cold/damp or direct sun. Check each TDS for limits.

q: How much paint do I need?
a: Area ÷ coverage = litres per coat. Example: 50 m² ÷ 10 m²/L = 5 L per coat. Multiply by number of coats; check the product’s stated coverage.

q: Do I need an undercoat on bare wood or metal?
a: Yes—prime first. Typical picks: Helmi Primer (interior wood), Otex Akva/Otex Adhesion (difficult surfaces), Rostex (metal), Ultra Primer (exterior wood).

q: Best system for kitchen cabinets?
a: Degrease, sand, then adhesion-prime (Otex Akva/Otex Adhesion). Topcoat with Helmi 10/30 or Everal Aqua 10/40/80 depending on sheen and durability preference.

q: Can I paint water-based over old oil-based paint?
a: Yes—wash, sand to de-gloss, use an adhesion primer (Otex Akva/Adhesion), then apply your water-borne topcoat.

q: Are your paints low VOC?
a: Many interior ranges are low-VOC and some zero-added-VOC when untinted. Exact VOC figures are listed on each product TDS.

q: Are your enamels suitable for radiators?
a: Yes—water-borne enamels like Everal Aqua and Helmi are used on radiators when primed correctly. Follow the product TDS for prep and heat limits.

q: How do I touch up ceilings without flashing?
a: Use a dead-matt like Anti-Reflex 2, apply thin, feather edges, and use the same batch and tool. Work corner-to-corner under similar lighting.

q: Do I need to sand between coats?
a: Lightly denib between coats once dry—especially on enamels and lacquers—to remove nibs and improve adhesion. Wipe dust off before recoating.

q: How do I paint fresh plaster?
a: Allow plaster to dry fully. Prime with a suitable wall primer (avoid PVA). Then apply your chosen topcoat (e.g., Optiva range). In humid rooms use the Luja system.

q: What should I do with chalky or very porous walls?
a: Brush/scrape off friable material, wash, let dry. Use a binding/priming coat per product TDS, then apply your finish. Heavily stained areas may need a stain-blocking primer.

q: What’s a typical system for exterior bare wood?
a: Prep (clean/sand), prime with an exterior wood primer (e.g., Ultra Primer), then finish with either an opaque (Valtti Opaque/Teho Modern) or translucent (Ultra Classic/Valtti Color) coating.

q: How do I deal with resinous knots and pitch bleed?
a: Remove resin mechanically and with suitable solvent, allow to dry, then prime. Severe knots may continue to exude; monitor and re-prime if needed before finishing.

q: I’m painting oak and getting brown stains—what is it?
a: Tannins can bleed through water-borne coats. Clean, allow to dry, and use a suitable tannin-inhibiting primer before your topcoat.

q: Which products are suitable for floors?
a: Concrete/previously painted floors: Betolux or Betolux Akva. Interior timber floors: Parketti Ässä lacquers (5/20/50/80) after proper prep and priming if required.

q: Which roller sleeve should I use?
a: Walls/ceilings with emulsion: medium pile microfibre (~9–12 mm). Woodwork/enamels: short pile (~4–6 mm) or foam/velour. Always test and follow TDS guidance.

q: Can I paint in cold or damp conditions?
a: Avoid low temperatures and high humidity. Most products need > +5°C and dry conditions. Drying and curing slow significantly in cold/damp—follow each TDS.

q: How do I store and dispose of paint?
a: Store sealed, upright, frost-free. Keep away from heat and direct sun. Do not pour leftovers down drains; take to local recycling/waste facilities as per local guidance.
